conclusion: To determine the power of the external force doing work, we need to consider the forces acting on the conductor rod and the work done by these forces.
The conductor rod is rotating with an angular velocity ω.
The magnetic field is uniform and has a magnetic induction intensity B.
The conductor frame is smooth and has negligible resistance.
The resistor R is connected between O and C.

premise: The magnetic force on the conductor rod is given by the equation F = BIL, where L is the length of the conductor rod.
conclusion: The magnetic field B is uniform, and the length L of the conductor rod is not provided. However, since the conductor rod is rotating, the magnetic force will be perpendicular to the direction of rotation.

premise: The work done by the magnetic force is given by W = 1/2mv^2, where m is the mass of the conductor rod and v is the velocity of the conductor rod.
conclusion: The velocity v of the conductor rod can be found using the equation v = ωr, where r is the radius of the conductor frame.

premise: Substituting v = ωr into the equation for work done by the magnetic force, we get W = 1/2m(ωr)^2 = 1/2mω^2r^2.
conclusion: The work done by the magnetic force is W = 1/2mω^2r^2.

premise: The power P of the external force doing work is given by P = W/t, where t is the time taken for the conductor rod to complete one full rotation.
conclusion: Since the conductor rod completes one full rotation in T = 2πr/ω, the power P is given by P = 1/2mω^2r^2 · 1/T.

premise: Substituting T = 2πr/ω into the equation for power, we get P = 1/2mω^2r^2 · 1/(2πr/ω) = 1/2mω^2 · 1/ω = 1/2m.
conclusion: The power of the external force doing work is 1/2m.
